revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} The '''Harvard-Navy lacrosse game of 1941''' was an [[college lacrosse|intercollegiate lacrosse]] game played in [[Annapolis, Maryland]], between the [[Harvard Crimson men's lacrosse|Harvard University Crimson]] and the [[Navy Midshipmen men's lacrosse|United States Naval Academy Midshipmen]] on April 4, 1941. Before the game, the Naval Academy's [[List of Superintendents of the United States Naval Academy|superintendent]] told Harvard that the Navy team would not play against a racially integrated team. Harvard's one [[African-American|black]] player, Lucien Alexis Jr. of New Orleans, left of his own accord after Harvard's athletic director told Harvard's coach to send him home. Harvard's players, supported by their coach, had voted to forfeit the game rather than play without him. The game went on as scheduled. Both Harvard's and the Naval Academy's administrations were criticized for their actions.
==Game== On April 3, 1941, the Harvard lacrosse team's 18 players arrived at [[Annapolis, Maryland]], to play the Naval Academy in a scheduled intercollegiate match. That day, the Naval Academy's superintendent, Rear Admiral [[Russell Willson]] discovered that Harvard's team included one black player, Lucien Alexis Jr. He informed Harvard's coach, Dick Snibbe, and athletic director, [[William J. Bingham]], that Navy's squad would not play against a racially integrated team.<ref>Gup, Doan, Fisher, p. 133.</ref>
Angry at the Naval Academy's stance, Snibbe and Alexis' teammates elected to forfeit the game and return to Harvard. Bingham intervened and ordered the Harvard coach to send Alexis home and play the game. Learning of Bingham's directive, Alexis voluntarily decided to depart and told his teammates that it was his idea. The game was played as scheduled the next day and Navy won 12-0.<ref>Gup, Doan</ref>
==Reaction== Harvard's student newspaper, ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'', learned of the incident and sharply criticized Bingham and Harvard's administration. The newspaper said of the incident:<ref name="Fisher, p. 133">Fisher, p. 133.</ref> {{quote|Those officials here who asked the negro to return to college should explain the reasons for their actions by which Harvard has [[Kowtow|kow-towed]] to [[Jim Crow laws|Jim-Crowism]]. Navy bigwigs should also be taught that when this country, this college and the navy itself declare their faith in democratic equality, they mean to practice what they preach.}} In response Bingham said: "We were guests of the Naval Academy and had no choice in the matter. Had the game been played at Cambridge, I would have insisted that he be allowed to participate."<ref name="Fisher, p. 133"/>
Newspapers in [[Boston]] and [[New York City]] picked up the story and criticized Harvard's and the Naval Academy's administrations for their actions. The [[Harvard Council for Democracy in Education]] complained to U.S. President [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]] about USNA's actions in the incident. The [[Harvard Corporation]] told Bingham and the Harvard Athletic Association to inform all future sports competitors that the school would not tolerate further racial discrimination against its student athletes.<ref>Gup, Doan, Fisher, p. 134.</ref>
One week after the incident, Alexis and the rest of Harvard's lacrosse team traveled to [[West Point]], [[New York (state)|New York]], to play a game against the [[United States Military Academy]]. In contrast to the reception the Navy had given Harvard's team, at West Point a cordon of cheering [[cadet]]s, led by black cadets attending the academy, welcomed Alexis and his team.<ref>Doan</ref>
[[Doris Kearns Goodwin]] counts this incident among several that pressured President Roosevelt, in June 1941, to sign [[Executive Order 8802]] that prohibited [[racial discrimination]] in the defense industry.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Goodwin |first1=Doris Kearns|title=No Ordinary Time: Franklin & Eleanor Roosevelt: The Home Front in World War II|date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=NY|pages=249ff.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hfv-AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA249& |accessdate=September 16, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Danelo>Danelo, 2005.</ref>
==Later events== In 1949 [[Wesley A. Brown]] was the first black student to graduate from the Naval Academy.<ref>Gup</ref> On May 10, 2008, a dedication ceremony was held on the Naval Academy campus for its newest building, the [[Wesley Brown Field House]], named for him.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rucker |first=Philip |title=Facility Dedicated to Black Pioneer: D.C. Resident Broke Institute's Color Barrier When He Graduated in 1949 |publisher=The Washington Post Company |date=May 11, 2008 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/10/AR2008051002435.html |accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name=Comprint>{{cite web |last=Green |first=Patrick (Trident staff) |title=Wesley Brown Field House Dedicated |date=May 15, 2008 |publisher=Comprint Military Publications ("Naval Academy on dcmilitary.com") |url=http://www.dcmilitary.com/stories/051508/trident_28234.shtml |accessdate=February 9, 2010 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130102210902/http://www.dcmilitary.com/stories/051508/trident_28234.shtml |archive-date=January 2, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Brown participated in the [[Ribbon cutting ceremony|ribbon-cutting ceremony]] with Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Adm. Mike Mullen, Naval Academy Superintendent Vice Adm. Jeffrey L. Fowler, and Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley. Also present were almost one thousand guests.
Lucien Victor Alexis (1887-1981), Harvard '17, was commissioned as a first lieutenant in the US Army and later became the principal of the only black high school in New Orleans.<ref>[http://www.creolegen.org/2014/05/05/the-negro-einstein/ "The Negro Einstein"], CreoleGen, 5 May 2014, accessed 12 February 2015</ref><ref>Harvard Class of 1918: ''Twenty-Fifth Anniversary Report'' (1943), Harvard University Archives; ''Orleans Parish School Board Minutes 9/23/1921, p.467 and 9/14/1923, p.336 (University of New Orleans)</ref> His son Lucien Victor Alexis, Jr. graduated from Harvard in turn and went into the service in World War II. After his return, he got a degree from [[Harvard Business School]]. He later served as head of a New Orleans business college for black students, segregated by state law. He married and had children. He died in 1975.<ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2008/11/17/class-report Roger Angell, "Class Report"], ''The New Yorker'', 17 November 2008, accessed 12 February 2015</ref> His daughter [[Lurita Alexis Doan]] became an entrepreneur, owning her own business from 1990 to 2005, and approved as the first woman and second African American to serve as Administrator of the [[General Services Administration]] (2006 to 2008), during the administration of President [[George W. Bush]].<ref name="Senate confirms FEMA, GSA chiefs">{{cite web |url=http://www.govexec.com/dailyfed/0506/052606d2.htm |title=Senate confirms FEMA, GSA chiefs |date=May 26, 2006 }}</ref><ref name="NYT043008">{{cite news |date= April 30, 2008 |last= Stout |first= David |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/01/washington/01doan.html |title= Federal Contracting Chief Is Forced Out |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate = February 12, 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Golden Thirteen]] *[[Port Chicago disaster]] *[[USS Kitty Hawk riot|USS ''Kitty Hawk'' riot]]
==References==
===Notes=== {{reflist}}
===Sources=== *{{cite web |last=Doan |first=Lurita |authorlink=Lurita Doan |date=August 2, 2009 |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/la-oe-doan2-2009aug02,0,4175835.story |title=On race, Harvard still must learn |format=Newspaper editorial |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=August 11, 2009 }} *{{cite book |last=Fisher |first=Donald M. |date=2002 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N8dQ11uQxrQC&pg=PA133&lpg=PA133&dq=1941+harvard+navy+lacrosse+game&source=bl&ots=i8r5uZ_TVS&sig=9LQ9sKGULrp76Vc1hAoemXtTSeE&hl=ja&ei=q2GfSuDxBpKAswO_hLXcDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4#v=onepage&q=1941%20harvard%20navy%20lacrosse%20game&f=false |title=Lacrosse: A History of the Game |publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Press |isbn=0-8018-6938-2}} *{{cite web |last=Gup |first=Ted |date=December 12, 2004 |url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/magazine/articles/2004/12/12/southern_discomfort/ |title=Southern Discomfort |format=Newspaper article |work=[[Boston Globe]] |accessdate=August 11, 2009 }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Harvard-Navy Lacrosse Game Of 1941}} [[Category:Racism]] [[Category:History of African-American civil rights]] [[Category:College lacrosse rivalries in the United States]] [[Category:History of racial segregation in the United States]] [[Category:Discrimination in the United States]] [[Category:African-American sports history]] [[Category:Navy Midshipmen men's lacrosse]] [[Category:Harvard Crimson men's lacrosse]] [[Category:United States Navy in the 20th-century]] [[Category:1941 in American sports]] [[Category:African-American history of the United States military]] [[Category:1941 in sports in Maryland|Harvard-Navy lacrosse]]

{{about|Albanians who live in [[Central Serbia]] and [[Vojvodina]]|the Albanians who live in partially recognized state of Kosovo|Kosovo Albanians}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Albanians in Serbia
Shqiptarët në Serbi
Албанци у Србији / Albanci u Srbiji | image = | population = '''5,809''' (2011 census)
'''~50,000''' (est.) | popplace = | region1 = [[Preševo]] | pop1 = 31,098 (2002 census) | ref1 = | region2 = [[Bujanovac]] | pop2 = 23,681 (2002 census) | ref2 = | region3 = [[Medveđa]] | pop3 = 2,816 (2002 census) | ref3 = | region4 = [[Vojvodina]] | pop4 = 2,251 (2011 census) | ref4 = | region5 = [[Belgrade]] | pop5 = 1,252 (2011 census) | ref5 = | langs = [[Albanian language|Albanian]] | rels = [[Sunni Islam]] (majority)
[[Bektashi Order|Bektashi]] (minority) }} {{Albanians}} '''Albanians in Serbia''' ({{lang-al|Shqiptarët në Serbi}}; {{lang-sr|Албанци у Србији / Albanci u Srbiji}}) are an officially recognized [[ethnic minority]] living in the present-day country of [[Serbia]]. ==Geography== In the municipalities of [[Preševo]] and [[Bujanovac]] Albanians form the majority of population (89.1% in Preševo and 54.69% in Bujanovac according to the 2002 census). In the municipality of Medveđa, Albanians are second largest ethnic group (after [[Serbs]]), and their participation in this municipality was 32% in 1981 census, 28.67% in 1991 and 26.17% in 2002.{{cite book|title=Popis stanovništva, domaćinstava i Stanova 2002. Knjiga 1: Nacionalna ili etnička pripadnost po naseljima|publisher=Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia|language=Serbian|year=2003|isbn=86-84433-00-9}} The region of Bujanovac and Preševo is widely known as the [[Preševo Valley]] (Serbian: Прешевска Долина, ''Preševska Dolina'', Albanian: ''Lugina e Preshevës''). There is a small community of Albanians in the [[Pešter]] region of [[Sandžak]] living in villages such as Boroštica, Doliće and Ugao. For the past two generations these villages have become partly ''bosniakicised'', due to intermarriage with the surrounding [[Bosniaks of Serbia|Bosniak]] population. As such and also due to the Yugoslav wars and thereafter, they have opted to declare themselves in censuses as "[[Muslims by ethnicity|Muslims]]" and "Bosniaks" instead of as Albanians to avoid problems. Elders in these villages are still fluent in Albanian.Andrea Pieroni, Maria Elena Giusti, & Cassandra L. Quave (2011). "Cross-cultural ethnobiology in the Western Balkans: medical ethnobotany and ethnozoology among Albanians and Serbs in the Pešter Plateau, Sandžak, South-Western Serbia." ''Human Ecology''. '''39'''.(3): 335. "The current population of the Albanian villages is partly “bosniakicised”, since in the last two generations a number of Albanian males began to intermarry with (Muslim) Bosniak women of Pešter. This is one of the reasons why locals in Ugao were declared to be “Bosniaks” in the last census of 2002, or, in Boroštica, to be simply “Muslims”, and in both cases abandoning the previous ethnic label of “Albanians”, which these villages used in the census conducted during “Yugoslavian” times. A number of our informants confirmed that the self-attribution “Albanian” was purposely abandoned in order to avoid problems following the Yugoslav Wars and associated violent incursions of Serbian para-military forces in the area. The oldest generation of the villagers however are still fluent in a dialect of Ghegh Albanian, which appears to have been neglected by European linguists thus far. Additionally, the presence of an Albanian minority in this area has never been brought to the attention of international stakeholders by either the former Yugoslav or the current Serbian authorities." ==History== In 1992, the Albanian representatives in the municipalities Preševo, Medveđa and Bujanovac organized a referendum in which they voted for the joining of these municipalities to the self-declared assembly of the [[Republic of Kosova]].[http://pashtriku.beepworld.de/kosovalindore.htm organized a referendum in which they voted that Preševo, Medveđa and Bujanovac should join Kosovo] However, no major events happened until the end of the 1990s. Following the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]], and nearby [[Kosovo War]] which lasted until 1999, between 1999 and 2001, an ethnic Albanian [[paramilitary]] separatist organization, the [[Liberation Army of Preševo, Medveđa and Bujanovac|UÇPMB]], raised an armed [[insurgency in the Preševo Valley]], in the region mostly inhabited by Albanians, with a goal to occupy these three municipalities from Serbia and join them to (future independent) Kosovo. Unlike in the case of Kosovo, western countries condemned the attacks and described it as the "extremism" and use of "illegal terrorist actions" by the group.{{cite book|author=European Centre for Minority Issues Staf|title=European Yearbook of Minority Issues: 2001/2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rkz7lvqGpDkC&pg=PA652|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers|isbn=90-411-1956-6|pages=652–}} Following the [[overthrow of Slobodan Milošević]], the new Serbian government suppressed the violence by 2001 and defeated the separatists. [[NATO]] troops also helped the Serbian government by ensuring that the rebels do not import the conflicts back into Kosovo, and even supported Serbia's military suppression of Albanians in their country, as an act to restore the relations with Serbia after 1999 bombing. This has left a dark chapter on Albania's relations with NATO, although Albania later joined the organization. Since then, the [[Albanian Coalition from Preševo Valley]] has gained representation in the [[National Assembly of Serbia]] where it holds two seats. In 2009, Serbia opened a military base [[Cepotina]] 5 kilometers south of Bujanovac, to further stabilize the area.{{cite news|title=Otvorena baza na jugu Srbije|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2009&mm=11&dd=23&nav_id=394131|accessdate=6 March 2017|work=b92.net|agency=Beta|date=23 November 2009|language=Serbian}} On 7 March 2017, the [[President of Albania]] [[Bujar Nishani]] made a historical visit to the municipalities of Preševo and Bujanovac, in which Albanians form the ethnic majority.{{cite news|title=Musliu: Albanski predsednik Bujar Nišani posetiće 7. marta Bujanovac i Preševo|url=http://www.blic.rs/vesti/politika/musliu-albanski-predsednik-bujar-nisani-posetice-7-marta-bujanovac-i-presevo/k5khx8q|accessdate=11 March 2017|work=blic.rs|agency=Beta|date=3 March 2017|language=Serbian}} ==Culture== Education in Albanian is provided for primary and secondary schools. There may be some university-level courses provided in Albanian, in the capital of Serbia, [[Belgrade]], but students mainly do their university degree in the [[Universiteti i Prishtinës|University of Prishtina]] in the Republic of Kosovo, in [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], or in [[Albania]]n Universities. The main religion of Albanians in this region is [[Islam]]. Prior to the [[Ottoman wars in Europe|Ottoman invasion of the Balkans]], the population of the Preševo Valley was mostly [[Roman Catholic]]. There are still Catholic churches in the Karadak villages, located in Kosovo today. ==Demographics== {{Historical populations | type = |1948|532011 |1953|565513 |1961|699772 |1971|984761 |1981|1303304 |1991|78281 |2002|61647 |2011|5809 | source = {{cite web|title=2011 Census of Population, Households and Dwellings in the Republic of Serbia |url=http://pod2.stat.gov.rs/ObjavljenePublikacije/Popis2011/Knjiga20.pdf |website=stat.gov.rs |publisher=Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia |accessdate=15 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714191241/http://pod2.stat.gov.rs/ObjavljenePublikacije/Popis2011/Knjiga20.pdf |archivedate=14 July 2014 }} | footnote = since 1991, the census was not conducted on the territory of [[Kosovo]]{{efn|name=status}} }} An estimate of 50,000{{cite web|title=South Serbia Albanians Seek Community of Municipalities|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/south-serbia-albanians-request-community-of-municipalities|accessdate=17 July 2013|quote=South Serbia is home to 50,000 or so Albanians.}}–70,000 {{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Albanians live in Serbia, a majority of whom live in the municipalities of [[Preševo]] ({{lang-al|Preshevë}}), [[Bujanovac]] ({{lang-al|Bujanoc}}), and part of the municipality of [[Medveđa]] ({{lang-al|Medvegjë}}). According to the results of the 2002 census, there were 61,467 ethnic Albanian citizens. Most Albanians boycotted the 2011 census, which resulted in only 5,809 Albanians being recorded as living in Serbia.{{cite web|url=http://media.popis2011.stat.rs/2012/Nacionalna%20pripadnost-Ethnicity.pdf|title=2011 Census of Population, Households and Dwellings in the Republic of Serbia: Ethnicity|date=2012|location=Belgrade|publisher=Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia|accessdate=17 February 2015}} Also, [[Belgrade]] has a minor Albanian community. In the census of 1981, 8,212 Albanians were registered. In 1991 there lived only 4,985 Albanians in Belgrade. After the [[Kosovo War]], this number decreased to 1,492, and according to the latest census (2011), the number is 1,252. ==Notable people== === Politics === * [[Kenan Evren]] – Turkish politician and military officer, who served as the 7th President of Turkey from 1980 to 1989 * [[Sinan Hasani]] – Yugoslav novelist, statesman, diplomat and a former President of Presidency Yugoslavia * [[Ivaz Mehmed Pasha]] – Ottoman-Albanian grand vizier and provincial governor * [[Aćif Hadžiahmetović]] – Albanian politician in the Sandžak region of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in the interwar period and during World War II * [[Ahmet Daca]] – Politician * [[Ali Shukriu]] – Politician * [[Ali Aliu]] – Albanian writer, economist, teacher, politician and political prisoner * [[Nexhat Daci]] – Kosovo-Albanian politician * [[Fatmir Hasani]] – Politician in Serbia * [[Muamer Zukorlić]] – Serbian politician, activist, and former President and Chief Mufti of the Islamic Community in Serbia === Military === * [[Idriz Seferi]] – Albanian nationalist figure and guerrilla fighter * [[Mazarek (vojvoda)|Mazarek]] – Serbian nobleman and general in the service of the Serbian Despotate * [[Džemail Koničanin]] – Military commander of the detachment of Sandžak Muslim militia === Cinema === * [[Bekim Fehmiu]] – Yugoslavian theater and film actor. He was the first Eastern European actor to star in Hollywood during the Cold War. === Arts and entertainment === * [[Fahri Beqiri]] – Albanian composer and former professor at the University of Prishtina Department of Music * [[Zana Nimani]] – pop singer * [[Donika Nuhiu]] – pop singer * [[Gold AG]] – rapper === Sports === * [[Taulant Xhaka]] – Albanian professional footballer who plays as a defensive midfielder for Swiss club Basel and the Albania national team * [[Granit Xhaka]] – Swiss-Albanian professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for English club Arsenal and the Switzerland national team. * [[Berat Djimsiti]] – Albanian professional footballer who plays for the Albania national team * [[Atdhe Nuhiu]] – Professional footballer who plays as a forward for English club Sheffield Wednesday and the Kosovo national team* [[Astrit Ajdarević]] – football player * [[Fidan Aliti]] – football player * [[Milot Rashica]] – football player * [[Bajram Jashanica]] – football player * [[Leart Paqarada]] – football player * [[Edon Zhegrova]] – football player * [[Arbnor Fejzullahu]] – football player * [[Alfred Ajdarević]] – football player * [[Arton Zekaj]] – football player * [[Ilaz Zylfiu]] – football player * [[Gjelbrim Taipi]] – football player * [[Dževad Prekazi]] – Former Yugoslav footballer who played as a midfielder * [[Leutrim Pajaziti]] – Albanian professional footballer who plays for Belgian club KVK Tienen * [[Mensur Limani]] – Kosovar-Albanian international footballer * [[Asmir Misini]] – Serbia football player === Media === * [[Mirko Gashi]], poet ==See also== * [[Albanians in Kosovo]] * [[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Albanians in Montenegro]] ==References== {{notes | notes = {{efn | name = status | {{Kosovo-note}} }} }} {| style="margin-left:13px; line-height:150%" |- | style="text-align:left;vertical-align:top;"|b.  |{{note|notes}}During the 2011 census, in the municipalities of Bujanovac and Preševo there was undercoverage of the census units owing to the boycott by most of the members of the Albanian ethnic community. |} {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090905232950/http://www.crisisgroup.org/home/index.cfm?l=1&id=4184 Southern Serbia: In Kosovo's Shadow] {{Ethnic Albanians}} {{Ethnic groups of Serbia}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Serbia]] [[Category:Albanians in Serbia| ]] [[Category:Albania–Serbia relations]] [[Category:Albanian communities in Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian people of Albanian descent| ]]

revision.comment: Bot: removing [[User:FrescoBot/Misplaced invisible LTR marks|misplaced invisible LTR marks]] and minor changes
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = | name = An American Dilemma | image = AnAmericanDilemma.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = First edition published by [[Harper & Brothers]] | author = [[Gunnar Myrdal]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = | set_in = | published = {{start date|df=yes|1944}} | publisher = | publisher2 = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} {{redirect|Negro problem|the musical group|The Negro Problem (band)}} {{italic title}} '''''An American Dilemma: The Negro Problem and Modern Democracy''''' is a 1944 study of [[race relations]] authored by [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Nobel-laureate]] [[economist]] [[Gunnar Myrdal]] and funded by [[Carnegie Corporation of New York]]. The foundation chose Myrdal because it thought that as a non-American, he could offer a more unbiased opinion. Myrdal's volume, at nearly 1,500 pages, painstakingly detailed what he saw as obstacles to full participation in American society that American [[Negro]]es faced as of the 1940s. [[Ralph Bunche]] served as Gunnar Myrdal's main researcher and writer at the start of the project in the Fall of 1938.<ref name=racebeat>{{cite book | author = [[Gene Roberts (journalist)|Roberts, Gene]] and [[Hank Klibanoff]] | title = [[The Race Beat|The Race Beat: The Press, the Civil Rights Struggle, and the Awakening of a Nation]] | publisher = [[Alfred A. Knopf]] | place = New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-679-40381-7}}</ref>
It sold over 100,000 copies and went through 25 printings before going into its second edition in 1965. It was enormously influential in how racial issues were viewed in the United States, and it was cited in the landmark ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]'' case "in general". The book was generally positive in its outlook on the future of race relations in America, taking the view that [[democracy]] would triumph over [[racism]]. In many ways it laid the groundwork for future policies of [[racial integration]] and [[affirmative action]].<ref name=racebeat />
== Analysis == Myrdal believed he saw a vicious cycle in which whites oppressed Negroes, and then pointed to Negroes' poor performance as reason for the oppression. The way out of this cycle, he argued, was to either cure whites of the prejudice he believed existed, or to improve the circumstances of Negroes, which would then disprove whites' preconceived notions. Myrdal called this process the "principle of cumulation".
In ''Black-White Relations: The American Dilemma'', economist Junfu Zhang gives this description of Myrdal's work:
{{quote|According to Myrdal, the American dilemma of his time referred to the co-existence of the American liberal ideals and the miserable situation of blacks. On the one hand, enshrined in the American creed is the belief that people are created equal and have human rights; on the other hand, blacks, as one tenth of the population, were treated as an inferior race and were denied numerous civil and political rights. Myrdal's encyclopedic study covers every aspect of black-white relations in the United States up to his time. He frankly concluded that the "Negro problem" is a "white man's problem". That is, whites as a collective were responsible for the disadvantageous situation in which blacks were trapped.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Zhang, Junfu | title = Black-White Relations: The American Dilemma | journal = Perspectives | publisher = Overseas Young Chinese Forum | volume = 1 | number = 4 | date = February 2000}} [http://www.oycf.org/Perspectives2/4_022900/black_white.htm (available online)]</ref>}}
Myrdal, writing before the [[Civil Rights Movement]] of the 1950s and 1960s, alleged that northern whites were generally ignorant of the situation facing Negro citizens, and noted that "to get publicity is of the highest strategic importance to the Negro people". This proved, given the pivotal role played by the press in the movement, to be strikingly prescient.<ref name=racebeat />
== American Creed == At the center of Myrdal's work in ''An American Dilemma'' was his postulate that political and social interaction in the United States is shaped by an "American Creed". This creed emphasizes the ideals of individualism, civil liberties, and equality of opportunity.<ref name=racebeat /><ref>Myrdal, Gunnar (1944). ''An American dilemma: The negro problem and modern democracy''. New York: Harper & Bros.</ref> Myrdal claims that it is the "American Creed" that keeps the diverse melting pot of the United States together. It is the common belief in this creed that endows all people—whites, negroes, rich, poor, male, female, and immigrants alike—with a common cause and allows for them to co-exist as one nation.<ref name=racebeat />
== See also == * [[Affirmative action]] * [[Gunnar Myrdal]] * [[Race relations]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Further reading == * [[Herbert Aptheker]], ''The Negro People in America: A Critique of Gunnar Myrdal's "An American Dilemma."'' New York: [[International Publishers]], 1946. * [[Ralph Ellison]]. "[http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/index.asp?document=554 ''An American Dilemma'': A Review]" (1944) * [[Eric Foner]] and [[John A. Garraty]]. ''The Reader's Companion to American History'', [[Houghton Mifflin]] Company. * Nikhil Pal Singh, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=rRxf3u1OZjAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=black+a+country&hl=en&ei=r4bCTtacMo2EtgfQgZXlDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Black is a country: race and the unfinished struggle for democracy]'' (2004) * [https://archive.org/details/AmericanDilemmaTheNegroProblemAndModernDemocracy An American Dilemma] at [[The Internet Archive]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:American Dilemma, An}} [[Category:1944 books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Sociology books]] [[Category:Politics and race in the United States]] [[Category:Books about African-American history]] [[Category:Harper & Brothers books]] [[Category:Race in the United States]] [[Category:Anti-black racism in the United States]] [[Category:Andrew Carnegie]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Baloch people in the United Arab Emirates |image = |population = '''468,000''' (2014)
5.08% of the UAE's population (2014) |popplace = [[Dubai]]{{·}} [[Abu Dhabi]]{{·}} [[Sharjah]]{{·}} [[Ajman]]{{·}} [[Ras Al Khaimah]]|langs = [[Balochi language|Balochi]]{{·}} [[Arabic language|Arabic]]
[[Brahui language|Brahui]], [[Persian language|Persian]],widely spoken as second/third languages |rels = [[Islam]]{{·}} [[Sunni]] }} '''Baloch people in the United Arab Emirates''' comprise residents of the [[United Arab Emirates]] whose ancestral roots lie in [[Balochistan]]. The Baloch are one of the oldest migrant groups in the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/nation/inside.asp?xfile=/data/community/2012/July/community_July3.xml§ion=community|title=Information desk for Pak Baloch community|work=Khaleej Times|date=2 July 2012|accessdate=18 May 2015}} The total population of the community is up to 468,000. ==History== Outside Balochistan, the largest [[Baloch diaspora]] communities reside in the [[Persian Gulf]] region, particularly [[Oman]] and the UAE.{{cite book|last1=Etheredge|first1=Laura|title=Persian Gulf States: Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, and the United Arab Emirates|date=2011|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=9781615303274|page=66|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=IM6J4sgCU28C&pg=PA66}} Many of the Baloch have been settled in the region before the formation of Pakistan and the UAE, forming part of the local [[Bedoon (ethnicity)|Bedoon]] community.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/heritage/bidoon-celebrate-uae-national-day-as-emiratis |title=Bidoon celebrate UAE National Day as Emiratis |work=The National |date=24 November 2013 |accessdate=10 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126150126/http://www.thenational.ae/uae/heritage/bidoon-celebrate-uae-national-day-as-emiratis |archivedate=November 26, 2013 }} The [[Balochistan region]] lies on the [[Iranian plateau]], located across the Persian Gulf. Due to the proximity between both regions, Baloch settlers have been in contact with the Persian Gulf since centuries. The Baloch are mentioned in Arabic chronicles dating back to the 10th century. The majority of Baloch migrants originate from the southern [[Makran]] coast.{{cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/tourism/sharjah-balochistan-flights-to-start-in-may-1.234248|title=Sharjah-Balochistan flights to start in May|work=Gulf News|date=25 April 2006|accessdate=23 July 2016|first=Nissar|last=Hoath}} Baloch who resided in the [[Trucial States]] prior to 1925 or before the formation of the union were offered the [[Emirati nationality law|Emirati citizenship]] as per Article 17 of the United Arab Emirates Citizenship and Passport Law of Year 1972.{{cite web|url=http://www.gcc-legal.org/LawAsPDF.aspx?opt&country=0&LawID=3147#Section_6582 |title=UAE Citizenship and Passport Law of Year 1972, Article 17 |accessdate=2018-01-23}} ==Demographics== The number of Baloch in the UAE is estimated to be anywhere from 215,000 to 468,000.{{cite book|last=Carina|first=Jahani|title=Standardization and Orthography in the Balochi Language|year=1989|publisher=Almqvist & Wiksell International|isbn=9789155424879}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/bcc|title=Balochi, Southern|work=[[Ethnologue]]|accessdate=18 May 2015}} The population has grown since 2006 when it was around 100,000. A number of Baloch serve in the UAE's [[Union Defence Force (UAE)|armed forces]].{{cite book|last1=Jahani|first1=Carina|title=The Baloch and their neighbours: ethnic and linguistic contact in Balochistan in historical and modern times|date=2003|publisher=Reichert|isbn=9783895003660}} The Baloch are divided into numerous [[List of Baloch tribes|tribes]]. These tribal networks extend into typically large connected families. One Baloch-Emirati man, Daad Mohammed Al Balushi, has 93 children and ranks among the world's [[list of people with the most children]].{{cite news|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/emirates/big-daad-with-93-kids-plans-to-marry-again-2013-04-30-1.504603|title='Big Daad' with 93 kids plans to marry again|work=Emirates 24/7|date=30 April 2013|accessdate=18 May 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/displayarticle.asp?xfile=data/theuae/2011/May/theuae_May713.xml§ion=theuae&col=|title=Daddy Cool!|work=Khaleej Times|date=24 May 2011|accessdate=18 May 2015|first=Nissar|last=Hoath}} ==Culture== The Baloch speak [[Balochi language|Balochi]]. The [[Gulf Arabic|Gulf dialect]] of [[Arabic language|Arabic]] is also natively spoken by those who have been settled in the region for generations.[[Brahui language|Brahui]] and [[Persian language|Persian]] are common second or third languages. A Balochi literary society under the name Balochi Labzanki Sarchammag is active in the UAE. In Balochi folklore, the Gulf is frequently referenced as a land of opportunities and employment. Poetry, lullabies or songs sung by women at weddings for instance contain references to the economic prosperity offered in Dubai. The surname [[Al Balushi]] denotes Baloch ancestry and is widely used among the local Baloch.{{cite web|url=http://rhawker.me/zayed-university/more-reflections-on-teaching-at-zayed-university/a-beginners-guide-to-society-in-the-uae/ |title=A Beginner’s Guide to Tribes in the UAE |first=Ron |last=Hawker |work=Digital Heritage in the UAE |date=2015 |accessdate=23 July 2016 |quote=Some tribes trace roots to other ethnic groups. Among the most important of these are the Baluch (or in Arabic, the Al Balooshi). Their ancestors came from the Baluchistan district split between Iran and Pakistan in the late 19th century. |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314205941/http://rhawker.me/zayed-university/more-reflections-on-teaching-at-zayed-university/a-beginners-guide-to-society-in-the-uae/ |archivedate=14 March 2016 |df= }} ==See also== {{Portal|Balochistan, Pakistan|Pakistan|Iran|Afghanistan|United Arab Emirates}} * [[Baloch diaspora]] * [[Pakistanis in the United Arab Emirates]] * [[Iranians in the United Arab Emirates]] * [[Afghans in the United Arab Emirates]] * [[Al Balushi]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Baloch diaspora}} {{Overseas Pakistani}} {{Iranian citizens abroad}} {{Afghan diaspora}} {{Immigration to the United Arab Emirates}} [[Category:Emirati people of Baloch descent| ]] [[Category:Baloch diaspora|United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Pakistani diaspora in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Iranian diaspora in the United Arab Emirates]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Disputed|date=October 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2009}} }}
The surname '''Bayat''' or '''Baiyat''' is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] clan name.
==Clans==
Bayat is the name of an originally [[Oghuz Turks|Turkic clan]] in Turkey, Azerbaijan and Iran which traces its origin to the 12th century. When Bayat clan started to migrate from the [[Kazakh Steppe|Aral steppes]], their first destination was the city of [[Neyshabur|Nishapur]] in the south of [[greater Khorasan|Khorasan]], a state in the north-east of [[Iran]]. The Bayat clan moved in the 13th century to three different locations after attacks by Mongol forces.
The Bayat clan made war with the [[Mongols]], killing [[Genghis Khan]]'s son-in-law with his army. Then Khan attacked Nishapur with all his forces, killing many Bayat clansmen, and the rest of the Bayat clan escaped to the mountains around Nishapur.
From there, one group went east and north-east, so that the surname Bayat is still found in [[Afghanistan]].{{cn|date=June 2015}} A second group went south-west towards Isfahan, and the surname Bayat is prominent in [[Arak, Iran|Arak]], [[Hamedan]], [[Malayer]], [[Isfahan]], [[Zanjan, Iran|Zanjan]] and [[Shiraz]]. The third group went north-west, and in [[Azerbaijan]] they divided in two; one part of the group took the west to [[Turkey|Anatolia]], and second part went south into [[Iraq]], [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]].
Bayat was the name of one of the 24 [[Oghuz Turks|Oghuz Turkish clans]] purported to descend from [[Oghuz Khaqan]] according to [[Oghuzname]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} and the oral legends prior to the writing of that book in the early 14th century. It is also the name of several localities and persons connected to the legend. In [[Afghanistan]], the clan is known to have who originally emigrated into the country with [[Nader Shah]].{{cn|date=May 2015}}
Notable figures from this clan include:{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} * Ata Korkut, legendary figure of the Oghuz * [[Fuzûlî]], famous [[Azeri]] poet of Ottoman era
==People with the name Bayat==
Bayat is a common surname today in [[Iran]], [[Azerbaijan]] and to a lesser extent in [[Turkey]], [[Afghanistan]],{{cn|date=June 2015}} and [[Turkmenistan]] where it carries the meaning "Knight" or "Chevalier".
Notable people with his name include: * [[Abbas Bayat]] (born 1947), Iranian businessman * [[Asef Bayat]], Iranian professor of sociology * [[Ehsan Bayat]], Afghan-American entrepreneur, owner of [[Ariana Television Network]] and founder of the Bayat Foundation<ref>[http://www.worldpress.org/Asia/2526.cfm The Bayat Foundation - Making a Difference in Afghanistan]. October 18, 2006. WorldPress.org.</ref> * [[Morteza Gholi Bayat]] (1890–1958), former Prime Minister of Iran
<!-- Do not add names here unless they have their own Wikipedia articles or independent reliable source references --> == See also== * [[Bayat (disambiguation)]] * [[Azerbaijani people]] * [[Qizilbash]] * [[Ansarlu]] * [[Kankalis]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Bisexuality topics sidebar}}'''Bisexual chic''' is a phrase used to describe the public acknowledgment of [[bisexuality]] or increased public interest or acceptance of bisexuality. Another usage describes a [[fad]]dish attention towards bisexuality.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/gayrights/story/0,12592,1115656,00.html US girls embrace gay passion fashion, The Observer, by Richard Luscombe, January 4, 2004]</ref> Bisexual chic is often accompanied by celebrities publicly revealing their bisexuality.
==Origin of term== In the United States, the 1920s was a decade of social experimentation, particularly with sex. This was heavily influenced by the writings of [[Sigmund Freud]], who theorized that people would behave in any manner to satisfy sexual desire. With the well-publicized image that sexual acts were a part of lesbian women and relationships, sexual experimentation was widespread. Large cities that provided a nightlife were immensely popular, and women began to seek out sexual adventure. Bisexuality became chic, particularly in America's first gay neighborhoods.<ref>Faderman, Lillian (1991). Odd Girls and Twilight Lovers: A History of Lesbian Life in Twentieth Century America, Penguin Books. pg63-67; {{ISBN|0-14-017122-3}}.</ref>
The phrase itself came into wide usage in the 1970s, on the tail end of the [[hippie]] movement, which extolled [[free love]]. During the [[glam rock]] and disco era, there was a media-generated fascination with bisexuality in the [[club scene]] and among musicians such as [[Elton John]], [[David Bowie]] and [[Patti Smith]]; in fact, in 1980, ''[[TIME|Time]]'' magazine referred to Bowie's persona [[David Bowie#Ziggy Stardust|Ziggy Stardust]] as "the orange-haired founder of bisexual chic."<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,920940-2,00.html Time magazine], Monday, Aug. 04, 1980</ref><ref>''Bisexuality in the United States: A Social Science Reader'' by Paula Claire Rust, 2000, pg 538</ref> At the same time, bisexual groups formed in several large [[United States|US]] cities, heralding the birth of the modern bisexual [[civil rights]] and [[liberation movement]]s.<ref>[http://www.binetusa.org/bihistory2.html A Brief History of the Bisexual Movement]</ref>
The phrase can be used to imply someone is only pretending to be bisexual because it’s fashionable at the moment.<ref>[http://www2.hu-berlin.de/sexology/BIB/bicent.htm San Francisco's Bisexual Center and the Emergence of a Bisexual Movement] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403194900/http://www2.hu-berlin.de/sexology/BIB/bicent.htm |date=April 3, 2007 }} by Jay P. Paul</ref> Alternatively, it can be used to assert that someone is free of taboos, experimental, in touch with both masculine and feminine aspects of themselves, and therefore potentially a better lover or even a better person.<ref>''Sex in Public: Australian Sexual Cultures'' by Jill Julius. Matthews; 1997, pg 75</ref>
== Emergence == Though the terminology is attributed to the 1970s, a bisexual trend occurred in the 1920s. In ''Vice Versa: Bisexuality and the Eroticism of Everyday Life'', [[Marjorie Garber]] argues "the twenties has been linked to the popularization of Freud (or "[[Freudianism]]"), the advent of World War I, and a general predilection for the daring and unconventional: [[bobbed hair]], short skirts, the rejection of [[Prohibition]] and [[Victorian morality|Victorian]] strictures." Examples of this include [[drag balls]], and the success of artists such as [[Ernest Hemingway]], [[D. H. Lawrence]], [[Virginia Woolf]], and [[Marlene Dietrich]].<ref name="Garber, Marjorie B. 1995">{{cite book |author=Garber, Marjorie B. |authorlink=Marjorie Garber |title=Vice versa: bisexuality and the eroticism of everyday life |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |year=1995 |isbn=0-684-80308-9}}</ref> Looking back from the 70s, writer [[Elaine Showalter]] accused Woolf and the [[Bloomsbury Group]] of bisexual chic when she warned Woolf and her friends of indulging "the fashion of bisexuality."<ref>[[Elaine Showalter]], A Literature of Their Own: British Women Novelists from Bronte to Lessing (Princeton University Press, 1977), p. 288.</ref>
== From 1970s onwards == After a strain of social movements centred on LGBT rights like the [[Stonewall riots|Stone Wall Riots]] in 1969, from 1970s onwards, awareness of bisexuality was on the rise and non-conforming sexual behaviors were seen as an act of social defiance. In 1972, the hit musical film ''[[Cabaret (1972 film)|Cabaret]]'' featured a love triangle with a man and woman fighting for the same (male) lover. The author who inspired it, [[Christopher Isherwood]], was among the first openly homosexual celebrities.<ref>[http://www.glbtq.com/literature/isherwood_c.html Christopher Isherwood on GLBTQ.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104004742/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/isherwood_c.html |date=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> Other prominent cultural representations of the 1970s include ''[[The Rocky Horror Picture Show]]'' and ''[[Sunday Bloody Sunday (film)]]''. In the 90s, under the influences of the contemporary [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipster]] subculture,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.micar.com/origins-of-the-hipster/|title=Where Did the Hipster Come From?|last=Digital|first=Andy Simpson @ Thunderbolt|date=2015-08-06|website=Micar Apparel Software|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> which symbolizes the resistance against mainstream lifestyle and encourages unconventionalities, more and more people started to speculate about their own identity as well as sexuality.
The phenomenon of bisexual chic can also be attributed to the growing number celebrities disclosing their bisexual identity. For example, in 1995, the lead vocalist of punk rock band [[Green Day]] [[Billie Joe Armstrong]] came out as bisexual in an interview with [[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/2010/03/14/billie-joe-armstrong-idiot-savant|title=Billie Joe Armstrong: Idiot Savant|date=2010-03-15|website=www.out.com|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> In the media, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s music videos for "[[Justify My Love]]" and "[[Erotica (song)|Erotica]]" and her book "[[Sex (book)|Sex]]" featured same-sex eroticism. Openly bisexual comedian [[Sandra Bernhard]] was featured as a bisexual on the popular television sitcom [[Roseanne]] amidst the trend. To illustrate the trend, Roseanne later found herself kissed by another woman and was "consoled" by Bernhard's character, bringing bisexuality to Middle America. (''See Also: [[Lesbian kiss episode]]s'') The 1992 film ''[[Basic Instinct]]'' featured a glamorous bisexual murderess played by [[Sharon Stone]]. Mainstream singer [[Janet Jackson]] recorded a [[cover version]] of [[Rod Stewart]]'s "[[Tonight's the Night (Gonna Be Alright)]]" in which she sings to a woman with whom she is about to engage in a ''[[ménage à trois]]'', saying, ''"This is just between me... and you... and you....".''
In the 21st century, bisexuality (or manifestations thereof) was alluded to in the films ''[[Kissing Jessica Stein]]'', ''[[Y tu mamá también]]'', ''[[Mulholland Drive (film)|Mulholland Drive]]'', ''[[Alexander (2004 film)|Alexander]]'', ''[[Kinsey (film)|Kinsey]]'', and ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]'', in the television series ''[[The O.C.]]'' in the US and ''[[Torchwood]]'' in the UK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2001320029-2006430699,00.html|title=Dr Ooh gets four gay pals|authorlink=|date=September 2006|publisher=The Sun|quote=GAY Doctor Who star John Barrowman gets four BISEXUAL assistants in raunchy BBC3 spin-off Torchwood.|accessdate=2006-10-06|author=Sarah Nathan|coauthors=}}</ref> and in Lady Gaga's music videos for "[[Lovegame|LoveGame]]" and "[[Telephone (song)|Telephone]]". In the 2003 [[MTV Video Music Award]]s, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] kissed [[Britney Spears]] and then [[Christina Aguilera]]; many news and tabloid outsources referred to it as "lesbian chic".<ref>http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1477729/20030828/spears_britney.jhtml?headlines=true</ref><ref>http://extratv.warnerbros.com/dailynews/extra/09_03/09_02c.html</ref> The 2008 hit song "[[I Kissed a Girl]]" by [[Katy Perry]] had bicurious lyrics. According to surveys by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] in the USA, a larger number of female college and high school students in America are experimenting with other women than ever before and, in a surprising twist, actually report being encouraged to do so by pop culture for the first time.<ref>[http://msnbc.msn.com/id/9358339 More women experimenting with bisexuality] from [[MSNBC|MSNBC.com]]</ref>
== Criticism == Despite the visibility and acceptance of bisexuality brought by the effects of bisexual chic, this phenomenon has been criticised for its "trendy" property rather than a genuine act of advocating bisexual equality. The idea of bisexuality being chic is also detrimental to the bisexual movement as "faux bisexuality" gives bad credits to bisexual people that their sexuality is only a form of art, not a real sexual orientation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedebrief.co.uk/news/real-life/why-all-these-public-displays-of-faux-lesbianism-need-to-stop-20140713768|title=Why All These Public Displays Of Faux-Lesbianism Need To Stop|website=The Debrief|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref>
It also misleads people who are [[bi-curious]], which means questioning their attraction to both sexes and possibly end up being [[Monosexuality|monosexual]], to identify with being bisexual.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hercampus.com/school/georgia-southern/bi-curious-vs-bisexual-do-some-girls-really-girls-or-attention|title=Bi-curious vs Bisexual. Do Some Girls REALLY Like Girls or Attention?|website=Her Campus|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Sexuality}} * [[Bisexual erasure]] * [[Lesbian until graduation]] * [[Monosexism]] * [[Sexual identity]] * [[Sexual orientation]] {{Clear}}
==References== <references />
== Related reading ==
* Beemyn, Brett and Erich Steinman. ''Bisexual Men in Culture and Society'' (Binghamton, NY: Haworth Press, 2001). * "The New Bisexuals." ''Time'', May 13, 1974. * [[Geoffrey K. Pullum]], "[http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/001421.html Bixexual chic: the facts]", September 6, 2004 ([[Language Log]]) * Reichert, Tom, Kevin R. Maly & Susan C. Zavoina. “Designed for (Male) Pleasure: The Myth of Lesbian Chic in Mainstream Advertising." Meta Carstarphen and Susan C. Zavoina (eds.), ''Sexual Rhetoric: Media Perspectives on Sexuality, Gender, and Identity'' (Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1999). * [[Barbara Risman|Risman, Barbara]] and Pepper Schwartz. "After the Sexual Revolution: Gender Politics in Teen Dating," ''Contexts'' (Berkeley: U California Press, 2002).
{{Bisexuality topics}}

revision.text:
{{hatnote|This article defines the legal definition of Bumiputera as defined in Brunei. For the definition of Bumiputera in terms of Malaysia, please see [[Bumiputera (Malaysia)]]}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Multiple issues| {{cleanup-rewrite|date=September 2009}} {{cleanup|date=September 2009}} {{refimprove|date=September 2009}} }} The '''Bumiputera''' or '''Bumiputra''' (from the [[Sanskrit]] word 'Bhumiputra' (भूमिपुत्र), which roughly translated means 'sons of the soil')<ref>Saunders, Graham (1994).''A History of Brunei'', p.192. Oxford University Press, Kuala Lumpur.</ref> also referred as '''Melayu Jati'''<ref>http://berita-utama.971100.n3.nabble.com/Pupuk-usaha-pelihara-warisan-budaya-Melayu-td4024269.html</ref> ("Indigenous Malays") in [[Brunei]] is the term used to refer to a member of majority [[Malays (ethnic group)|Malay]] [[ethnic group]] and members of certain native groups as outlined below.
==Definition== The [[Brunei]] [[Constitution]] defines a '''Bumiputera''' as a member of the following ethnic groups: [[Bruneian Malay people|Bruneian Malay]], [[Tutong people|Tutong]], [[Belait people|Belait]], [[Dusun people|Dusun]], [[Murut people|Murut]], [[Kedayan]], and [[Bisaya (Borneo)|Bisaya]].
Other indigenous peoples (e.g. [[Iban people|Iban]], [[Kelabit people|Kelabit]] and [[Penan]]) are not defined as being Bumiputera by the Brunei constitution, nor are citizens who are of ethnic-Chinese, Indians or of Caucasian ancestry. Race is patrilineally defined in Brunei, so, for example, a half-Chinese man with an ethnic Dusun father is considered to be Bumiputera.
This is different from the definition in Malaysia where a larger number of races and ethnic groups are considered as [[Bumiputra]]. The Malaysian Constitution does not actually provide a definition of the term, which has led to some controversy concerning its relation to the indigenous groups in that country. See [[Bumiputera (Malaysia)]]. Constitutional references to Bumiputeras can be found in Section 160 (2) of the Constitution of Brunei Darassalam.
==Precedence== Being accorded the status of Bumiputera in Brunei (as in Malaysia) carries with it certain benefits and opportunities which other ethnic groups in the country may not have access to.<ref name="unhcr.org">Minority Rights Group International, World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples - Brunei Darussalam : Dusun, Murut, Kedayan, Iban, Tutong, Penan, 2008, available at: http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/49749d48c.html [accessed 3 August 2009]</ref> There are a number of [[affirmative action]] items targeting the Bumiputeras in Brunei. Under special legislation they have extended land rights and are given special privileges for employment opportunities in the [[Royal Brunei Armed Forces]] and Brunei Shell Petroleum.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}
The justification for these special privileges and affirmative action schemes is that Bumiputeras face disadvantages due to the success of other groups in society, for example the Chinese.<ref>Gunn, Geoffrey (1997). ''Language, Power, and Ideology in Brunei Darussalam '', p.7. Ohio University Center for International Studies, Ohio.</ref> One case of such disadvantage can be seen in the demise of the construction industry in Brunei. The building sector is a major employer of Bumiputeras and forms the lifeblood of many Bumiputera families.<ref>Gunn, Geoffrey (2008). 'Brunei Darussalam: Dynastic Fallout, Economic Crisis and Recovery' Nagasaki University's Academic Output Site http://hdl.handle.net/10069/20942, accessed 3 August 2009</ref> As such, they are the group in society most affected by the global economic crisis. In the past, government policies in relation to economic recovery has been directly focussed on improving the position of Bumiputeras. During the Asian Economic Crisis of the late 1990s, Brunei's Economic Council developed an Action Plan to increase economic activity and thereby bring about some form of relief. A major part of that plan was to actively encourage and subsidise investment in Bumiputera-owned businesses.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}
==Bumiputera and Islam== The term Bumiputera often connotes those people of Malay-speaking ethnic groups who belong to the Islamic faith. Indeed, it has become advantageous for Bruneians to convert to Islam to truly qualify for Bumiputera status.<ref>Gunn, Geoffrey (1997). ''Language, Power and Ideology in Brunei Darussalam'', pp.6-7. Ohio University Center for International Studies, Ohio</ref> There are some concerns that members of indigenous groups who technically fall under the Bumiputera category, but do not belong to the Islamic faith, may be under official pressure to convert to maintain their rights and privileges.<ref name="unhcr.org"/> In the 1970s, many indigenous people converted to Islam for this reason.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} The Bruneian government bans many religious activities not related to Islam, while at the same time benefitting those who participate in activities conducted by Muslim groups.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} This increases disadvantages to indigenous Bumiputeras who are not Muslims.
==Comparing the concept of Bumiputera privileges in Malaysia and Brunei== Whereas the delineation between Bumiputeras and other groups in Malaysia has been the cause of much conflict and unrest of late, it does not appear to have had the same consequences in Bruneian society. This may be because [[affirmative action]] strategies are not so prevalent or obvious in Bruneian society. A lack of opposition to the Bumiputera concept in Brunei may also be because as an autocratic sultanate, the country does not experience a great deal of political diversity.<ref>Economist Intelligence Unit (2008).''Country Profile/Report'', Malaysia, Brunei</ref> This is in contrast to the situation in Malaysia, where protests against Bumiputera privileges in Malaysia are often backed by opposition parties to raise dissatisfaction with the government.<ref>[[Bumiputera (Malaysia)]]</ref>
==See also== *[[Malayness]] **[[Pribumi]] *[[Malay world]] *[[Malay Archipelago]] *[[East Indies]] *[[Malay race]] *[[Maphilindo]] *[[Nusantara]] *[[Greater Indonesia]]
==Notes and references== {{reflist|35em}}
[[Category:Bruneian society]] [[Category:Ethnic supremacy|Brunei]]

[[Image:Jorge Andrade 31mar2007.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Jorge Andrade]]]] [[Image:Luís Miguel Brito 24sept2006.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Luís Miguel Brito]]]] [[Image:Veiga, Jose.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[José Veiga (born 1976)|José Veiga]]]]
In 1995, it was estimated that there were 50,000 people of [[Cape Verde]]an descent or national origin in [[Portugal]].<ref>[http://www.umassd.edu/SpecialPrograms/CaboVerde/wwpopest.html 1995 Cape Verdean Diaspora Population Estimates] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090829094133/http://www.umassd.edu/SpecialPrograms/CaboVerde/wwpopest.html |date=2009-08-29 }}</ref> By 2000, this estimation rose to 83,000 people, of which 90% resided in Greater Lisbon."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080229205609/http://www.iss.co.za/index.php?link_id=21&slink_id=1774&link_type=12&slink_type=12&tmpl_id=3 Marc-Montclos, Antoine Pérouse de. " The Political Value of Remittances: Cape Verde, Comores, and Lesotho - Diasporas, Remittances and Africa South of the Sahara - A Strategic Assessment." Institute for Security Studies. Retrieved October 18, 2007.]</ref> In 2008, Portugal’s National Statistics Institute estimated that there were 68,145 Cape Verdeans who legally resided in Portugal. This made up "15.7% of all foreign nationals living legally in the country."<ref>[http://www.asemana.cv/article.php3?id_article=28328 A Semana. "Cape Verdeans make up 15.7% of all foreigners in Portugal." Retrieved January 20, 2008.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229180245/http://www.asemana.cv/article.php3?id_article=28328 |date=February 29, 2008 }}</ref>
==Notable people== *[[Germano Almeida]] writer *[[Ângela Maria Fonseca Spínola]] *[[Cláudio Aguiar]] *[[Jorge Andrade]] *[[Hernâni Borges]] *[[Nelson Évora]] *[[Arlindo Gomes Semedo]] *[[José Gonçalves (footballer)|José Gonçalves]] *[[Sara Tavares]] *[[Néné da Luz]] *[[Nélson Marcos]] *[[Sandro Mendes]] *[[Vítor Moreno]] *[[Nani]] *[[Nilton Fernandes]] *[[Pedro Pelé]] *[[Rolando (Portuguese footballer)|Rolando]] *[[Manuel Estêvão Sanches]] *[[Ernesto da Conceição Soares]] *[[Marco Soares (football)|Marco Soares]] *[[Edson Rolando Silva Sousa]] *[[José Veiga (born 1976)|José Veiga]] *[[Nélson Veiga]] *[[João Gomes (basketball)|João Gomes]], basketball player *[[Cristiano Ronaldo]] *[[Lura (musician)|Lura]] singer *[[Oceano da Cruz]] *[[Renato Sanches]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/po.html Central Intelligence Agency. "Portugal." The World Factbook. Retrieved October 18, 2007.]
{{Cape Verdean diaspora}} {{Immigration to Portugal}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Infobox Newspaper | name = No More Fun and Games | image = NMFaG issue 2.JPG | caption = ''No More Fun and Games'', Issue 2 | type = [[Political philosophy]] | format = Irregular newspaper | owners = Cell 16 | foundation = 1968 | ceased publication = 1973 | language = [[english language|English]] | political = [[Feminism]] | circulation = | headquarters = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] | italic title = no }} '''Cell 16''' was a militant [[feminist]] organization in the United States known for its program of [[celibacy]], separation from men and self-defense training (specifically [[karate]]).<ref>Bevacqua, Maria. ''Rape on the Public Agenda: Feminism and the Politics of Sexual Assault'' (2000) {{ISBN|1-55553-446-5}}</ref><ref name="Echols, Alice 1990, p164">Echols, Alice. ''Daring to Be Bad: Radical Feminism in America, 1967-75'', University of Minnesota Press, 1990, {{ISBN|0-8166-1787-2}}, p164</ref> Considered too extreme by many mainstream feminists, the organization acted as a sort of [[hard left]] [[Vanguardism|vanguard]].<ref>Heath and Potter. ''Feminism For Sale''. ''[[This Magazine]]'' (2005) {{cite web|url=http://www.thismagazine.ca/issues/2005/05/feminism.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071022080224/http://thismagazine.ca/issues/2005/05/feminism.php |archivedate=2007-10-22 |df= }}</ref>
==Ideology== Founded in 1968 by [[Roxanne Dunbar]], Cell 16 has been cited as the first organization to advance the concept of [[separatist feminism]].<ref name="Echols, Alice 1990, p164" /><ref>Saulnier, Christine F. ''Feminist Theories and Social Work: Approaches and Applications'' (1996) {{ISBN|1-56024-945-5}}</ref> Cultural Historian [[Alice Echols]] cites Cell 16 as an example of feminist ''heterosexual separatism'', as the group never advocated lesbianism as a political strategy. Echols credits Cell 16's work for "helping establishing the theoretical foundation for [[lesbian separatism]].<ref name="Echols, Alice 1990, p164" /> In ''No More Fun and Games'', the organization's radical feminist periodical, Cell Members Roxanne Dunbar and Lisa Leghorn advised women to "separate from men who are not consciously working for female liberation" and advised periods of celibacy, rather than lesbian relationships, which they considered to be "nothing more than a personal solution."<ref>Dunbar, Leghorn. ''The Man's Problem'', from ''No More Fun and Games'', November 1969, quoted in Echols, 165</ref>
==History== In the Summer of 1968, Dunbar placed an ad in a [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] underground newspaper calling for a "Female Liberation Front." The original membership also included Hillary Langhorst, Sandy Bernard, [[Dana Densmore]], the daughter of [[Donna Allen (feminist)|Donna Allen]], Betsy Warrior, Ellen O'Donnell, Jayne West, Mary Anne Weathers, Maureen Maynes, Gail Murray, and [[Abby Rockefeller]].<ref>Endres and Lueck. ''Women's Periodicals in the United States: Social and Political Issues'' (1996) {{ISBN|0-313-28632-9}}</ref><ref name="Echols, Alice 1990">Echols, Alice. ''Daring to Be Bad: Radical Feminism in America, 1967-75'', University of Minnesota Press, 1990, {{ISBN|0-8166-1787-2}}</ref> The group's name was meant "to emphasize that they were only one cell of an organic movement" and referenced the address of their meetings — 16 Lexington Avenue.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cambridgema.gov/cwhp/bios_c.html |title=Cambridge Women's Heritage Project |access-date=2007-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128225509/http://www.cambridgema.gov/cwhp/bios_c.html#Cell16 |archive-date=2010-01-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
''No More Fun and Games'' ceased publication in 1973.<ref>[http://www.greenlion.com/NMFG/nmfg.html ''No More Fun and Games, A Journal of Female Liberation'']</ref> Cell 16 disbanded in 1973 as well.<ref name="Echols, Alice 1990" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * Pearson, Kyra. ''Mapping rhetorical interventions in "national" feminist histories: Second wave feminism and Ain't I a Woman''. (1999) [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3669/is_199907/ai_n8828807/pg_1] {{dead link|date=October 2013}} * Duke University has digitized vol. 1, no. 2 of the journal "No More Fun and Games" [http://library.duke.edu/digitalcollections/wlmpc_wlmms01029/]
== Further reading == * ''The Female state.'' Cambridge, Massachusetts : Cell 16. (1970) [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/478356868 OCLC 478356868]
[[Category:Women's political advocacy groups in the United States]] [[Category:Celibacy]] [[Category:Feminism and sexuality]] [[Category:Feminist organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1968]] [[Category:Radical feminist organizations]] [[Category:History of women in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1973]] [[Category:1968 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:1973 disestablishments in Massachusetts]]

revision.text:
[[File:Central Jail of Nicosia watch post.JPG|thumb|right|160px|Watch post in Nicosia Central Jail.]] The '''Central Jail of Nicosia''' is the only [[correctional facility]] in [[Cyprus]]<ref name="GOV">{{cite web|url=http://www.cyprus.gov.cy/portal/portal.nsf/All/8D1190D346BABF91C2257014005189FC?OpenDocument|title=Defence - Security - Prisons Department|work=Cyprus Government Web Portal|publisher=cyprus.gov.cy|accessdate=2009-04-27}}</ref> and it is run by the [[Cyprus Prisons Department]]. It is located to the west of the walled part of the Cypriot city of [[Nicosia]], south of the [[Green Line (Cyprus)|Green Line]]. In the facility are detained convicted and unconvicted prisoners of both sexes and of all age groups from 16 years and over.<ref name="GOV" />
The Nicosia central prison was built by the [[United Kingdom|British]] in 1894 and were in use until 1955 as a place of detention of those condemned by the courts to imprisonment, but also as a place of temporary detention of persons under judicial decree.
It is known primarily for the "[[Imprisoned Graves]]" where 13 [[EOKA]] fighters were interred. Nine of them were hanged by the British, three were killed in action and one died in hospital from his battle wounds.
During the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus]] (1974) battles raged around the Central Jail of Lefkosia. Vastly outnumbered, the Cypriot national guardsmen - aided by corrections officers - managed to fight off the Turks and keep the jail with its Imprisoned Tombs from being captured.
==See also== * [[Büyük Han]]
==References== <references />
==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Central Jail of Nicosia}}
{{coord|35|10|48.47|N|33|20|40.44|E|region:CY|display=title}}

{{Infobox UCR |city_name=Atlanta |year=2015 |homicide=105 |forcible_rape=170<sup>**</sup> |robbery=1,995 |aggravated_assault=2,944 |violent_crime=5,203 |burglary=4,781 |larceny_theft=16,493 |motor_vehicle_theft=4,282 |property_crime=25,556 |source_url=https://ucr.fbi.gov/crime-in-the-u.s/2015/crime-in-the-u.s.-2015/tables/table-8/table-8-state-pieces/table_8_offenses_known_to_law_enforcement_georgia_by_city_2015.xls |source_name=FBI 2015 UCR data |arson = 50 |notes=** Legacy definition<ref>{{cite web|title=FBI|url=https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/cjis/ucr/crime-in-the-u.s/2013/crime-in-the-u.s.-2013/rape-addendum/rape_addendum_final|website=Fbi.gov|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref> }} '''Crime in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]''' is above the national [[median]] and has been a major problem for the city since the middle 20th century.
Atlanta’s public safety improvement between 2001 and 2009 occurred at more than twice the rate of the rest of the country.<ref name="auto">{{cite news |url=http://www.ajc.com/opinion/how-to-create-a-711260.html |title=How to create a safer Atlanta |first=David |last= Edwards |date=November 1, 2010 |work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101109075330/http://www.ajc.com/opinion/how-to-create-a-711260.html |archivedate=November 9, 2010 |accessdate=January 25, 2017 }}</ref> After ranking in the top five highest violent crime cities for most of the previous three decades, in 2009 Atlanta ranked 31st,<ref name="auto"/> and in 2015, 24/7 Wall Street ranked it 19th.<ref>[http://247wallst.com/special-report/2016/09/27/25-most-dangerous-cities-in-america/3/ ''The Most Dangerous Cities in America'', page 3], 24/7 Wall Street, September 27, 2016. Retrieved February 18, 2017.</ref> While various news sources report rankings by crime rate, FBI strongly cautions against this, because this is a misuse of bare statistics, since it ignores various important factors, such as population density, degree of urbanization, composition of population, economic conditions, etc. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://ucr.fbi.gov/ucr-statistics-their-proper-use|title="Uniform Crime Reporting Statistics: Their Proper Use"|website=Ucr.fbi.gov|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Atlanta Police GA USA - Ford Crown Victoria (1).jpg|thumb|250px|An Atlanta [[police car]] ]] During the 1970s, like with many large cities within the [[United States]], Atlanta's population began to decline. By 1990, the population was 394,017, down almost 20% from its population in 1970, which was 496,973.<ref name="populationdivision,laurak.yax">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0027/twps0027.html|title=Population of the 100 Largest Cities and Other Urban Places In TheUnited States: 1790 to 1990|author=Population Division, Laura K. Yax|website=Census.gov|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref> In addition, the city center and surrounding areas began to go through an [[urban decay]], and crime spiked significantly throughout the 1980s. Along with many other major cities in the United States, Atlanta was hard hit by the [[crack epidemic (United States)|crack epidemic]] of most of the 1980s to early 1990s. In 1994, Atlanta was ranked the most dangerous city in the country by the [[Morgan Quitno Press]].<ref>[http://www.morganquitno.com/1st_safest.htm The First Safest/Most Dangerous City Listing]. Morgan Quitno Press. Lawrence, Kansas, United States. 1994.</ref>
In 1997, [[drug-related crime]] in [[metro Atlanta]] increased slightly, in part due to Atlanta becoming an important distribution center for [[cocaine]], and other related [[illegal drug|drug]]s [[Mexican Drug War|imported from Mexico]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2008/09/15/daily55.html | date=September 17, 2008 | title=Major cocaine and marijuana ring busted in Atlanta|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2008/10/27/daily52.html?q=cocaine%20in%20Atlanta | date=October 29, 2008 | title=Mexican drug cartel busted up in Atlanta|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref> These increases were mostly seen in [[Fulton County, Georgia|Fulton]], [[Gwinnett]], [[DeKalb County, Georgia|DeKalb]], [[Cobb County|Cobb]], and [[Clayton County, Georgia|Clayton]] counties. Many [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] agencies in the area have joined forces together with the [[Atlanta Police Department]] in an effort to decrease the overall crime in metro Atlanta.<ref>[http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/stories/2009/05/27/police_crime_sweep.html] {{dead link|date=October 2017}}</ref>
In addition, due to large amounts of [[urban renewal|revitalization]] projects in the city core, crime continued to fall, even amidst the hard economic times of the late-2000s/early 2010s.<ref name="populationdivision,laurak.yax"/>
==Policing== The city is served by the [[Atlanta Police Department]]. In 2013, the APD had 2,000 officers,<ref name="Godwin">Becca J. G. Godwin, [http://www.ajc.com/news/local/atlanta-homicides-from-2016-remain-unsolved-these-are-the-victims/UelLUXycTlEOJTJ7mqKf6N/ 51 Atlanta homicides from 2016 remain unsolved. These are the victims], ''Atlanta Journal Constitution'' (February 15, 2017).</ref><ref name="Shapiro">Jonathan Shapiro, [http://news.wabe.org/post/2000-atlanta-police-officers-gripes-remain-over-pay 2,000 Atlanta Police Officers, But Gripes Remain Over Pay], WABE (October 25, 2013).</ref><ref>Katie Leslie, [http://www.myajc.com/news/local/apd-reaches-once-elusive-goal-000-officers/Ao9jWRR0M23HJNKApTJP1L/ APD reaches a once-elusive goal of 2,000 officers], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (October 25, 2013).</ref> but the number of officers has decreased since that time.<ref name="Godwin"/> Mayor [[Kasim Reed]] has identified an increase in the number of officers to 2,000 as a goal for the city.<ref name="Godwin"/> Although city data shows that APD attrition rates have improved from the 2000s to 2013, morale issues within the police department has persisted due to officer dissatisfaction with salaries.<ref name="Shapiro"/> About 45 percent of officers hired between 2005 and 2013 left the force by 2017.<ref name="Boone">Christian Boone, [http://www.myajc.com/news/crime--law/murders-atlanta-are-way-but-overall-crime-way-down/dBSfTIdF7afBJ38yGmqVrM/ Murders in Atlanta are way up, but overall crime is way down], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (January 31, 2017).</ref> Atlanta is divided into six police patrol zones.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantapd.org/about-apd/zone-maps|title=Atlanta Police Department : Zone Maps|website=Atlantapd.org|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref>
The [[Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority]] (MARTA), which operates rail, bus, and parking lots in the city and surrounding area, has its own police force. Overall crime rates in are about 30 per every 100,000 system daily riders, which is identical to the crime figure for the [[Washington, D.C. area]]'s [[Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority|WMATA]], higher than crime figure for the Boston area's [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority|MBTA]], and lower than the crime figure for the San Francisco area's [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]]. Homicides within the MARTA system have varied. In the [[fiscal year]] ending in 2017, for example, there were four homicides investigated by MARTA police, but there were no homicides in the MARTA system in any of the previous last four fiscal years.<ref name="SharpeMARTA">Joshua Sharpe, [http://www.ajc.com/news/local/after-recent-killings-how-safe-marta/KUtM1GmuvSiNsKFs1Ln58L/ After recent killings, how safe is MARTA?], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (February 16, 2017).</ref> Total crimes in the MARTA system have declined from fiscal year 2013.<ref name="SharpeMARTA"/>
==Crime rates and trends== From 2009 to 2016, overall crime in Atlanta declined 27 percent, "with sharp declines in burglaries (9,102 in 2009 to 4,377 in 2016), robberies (2,622 to 1,914) and aggravated assaults (2,602 to 2,179)."<ref name="Boone"/>
===Homicide=== Consistent with national trends, the murder rate in Atlanta peaked in 1990 and have declined since.<ref>Bryan Cronan, [http://www.atlantamagazine.com/crime-city/the-homicide-report/ The Homicide Report], ''Atlanta Magazine'' (May 15, 2014).</ref> From 2000 to 2010, murders in the city declined by nearly 50 percent.<ref name="Boone"/> The years 2009 and 2012 had the lowest numbers of homicides in Atlanta than any year dating back to 1963,<ref>Marcus K. Garner, [http://www.ajc.com/news/crime--law/atlanta-homicides-2nd-lowest-years/5KZDukpRGDMGUwXb5maL4K/ Atlanta homicides 2nd lowest in 50 years], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (January 10, 2013).</ref> but there has been an increase in murders in the city beginning in 2013.<ref name="Boone"/> The number of murders in Atlanta was 80 in 2009, 92 in 2010, 88 in 2011, 85 in 2012, 82 in 2013, 93 in 2014, 95 in 2015, and 111 in 2016.<ref name="Boone"/> A significant number of murders have remained unsolved; as of February 2017, 51 of the 111 homicides from 2016 remain unsolved.<ref name="Godwin"/>
An analysis of FBI [[Uniform Crime Report]] data for 2015, conducted by the economic analysis website 24/7 Wall Street, showed a murder rate in Atlanta of about 20.2 per 100,000 people, making it the 18th highest murder rate among U.S. cities.<ref name="Pirani">Fiza Pirani, [http://www.ajc.com/news/crime--law/atlanta-named-one-america-top-murder-capitals/iazY5cSkTgXxs436eN8chL/ Atlanta named one of America's top 'murder capitals'], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (November 2, 2016).</ref> A October 2016 ''[[FiveThirtyEight]]'' analysis of preliminary 2016 data, taken from official police information and local reports, found that among U.S. cities with populations of over a quarter-million people, Atlanta had the tenth-highest murder rate, at 23.9 per 100,000 residents.<ref>Jeff Asher, [https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/u-s-cities-experienced-another-big-rise-in-murder-in-2016/ A Handful Of Cities Are Driving 2016's Rise In Murders], ''FiveThirtyEight'' (October 6, 2016).</ref>
[[Fulton County, Georgia|Fulton County]] District Attorney Paul Howard said that 17% of 2014 homicides in the county were gang-related.<ref name="BooneGangs">Christian Boone, [http://www.myajc.com/news/crime--law/violent-crime-fueled-gangs-the-rise-atlanta/rPSsKPTcDm4qLg34iHle6N/ Violent crime fueled by gangs on the rise in Atlanta], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'' (July 1, 2015).</ref> In Atlanta, guns were involved in 82% of homicide cases.<ref name="Pirani"/> In July 2016, in an attempt to combat an increase in homicide, the city began Operation Whiplash, with additional police officers and other resources assigned to 33 "challenging and crime-ridden" neighborhoods in the city.<ref name="Boone"/><ref>[http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/local/story/2016/jul/05/murder-rate-rises-atlanta-aims-get-guns-streets/374393/ As murder rate rises, Atlanta aims to get guns off streets], Associated Press (July 5, 2016).</ref>
==Gang crime== [[Street gang]]s of various levels of sophistication have had a presence in the city since the late 1970's. In 2015, Atlanta police were tracking about 192 gangs, more than double the number identified six years earlier.<ref name="BooneGangs"/> The supervisor of the FBI's Atlanta Safe Streets Gang Task Force<ref name="Econ">[https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21654076-what-gangs-can-offer-young-asian-americans-fighting-back Crime in Atlanta: Fighting back: What gangs can offer young Asian-Americans], ''The Economist'' (July 11, 2016).</ref> said in 2016 that more than half of violent crime in the city was involved gang members.<ref>Mark Winne, [http://www.wsbtv.com/news/2-investigates/metro-atlantas-gang-problem-larger-than-ever-before/466378876 Metro Atlanta's gang problem larger than ever before], WSB-TV (November 14, 2016).</ref> In addition to violent crime, [[drug dealing]], and [[carjacking]], some Atlanta gangs committ [[identity theft]] and [[credit card fraud]].<ref name="Econ"/>
==Human trafficking== {{Main|Human trafficking in Georgia (U.S. state)#Atlanta}} Atlanta is now a major transportation hub when it comes to trafficking young girls from Mexico and is one of the fourteen U.S. cities with the highest levels of sex trafficking of children.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/priority-areas/civil-rights/human-trafficking|title=Civil Rights Prosecutions: Human Trafficking {{!}} USAO {{!}} Department of Justice|website=Justice.gov|access-date=2016-04-18}}</ref>
In the year of 2007 the sex trade generated $290 million in Atlanta.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.streetgrace.org/georgia-laws/|title=Georgia Laws|website=Street Grace, Inc|access-date=2016-04-18}}</ref>
Since Atlanta has “the same ready access to commercial air and ground routes that draws businesses and travelers to Atlanta also entices criminals engaged in human trafficking”. There are numerous events and conventions in Atlanta that bring many people to the city which also exemplifies the issue.<ref name=":1" />
==Notable incidents== *[[Atlanta murders of 1979-1981]] — A [[serial killing|series of murders]] that started from the summer of 1979 and ended in the spring of 1981. Twenty children were killed in this incident. *[[Atlanta Prison Riots]] — A series of riots in 1987. One hundred people were made hostage and a portion of the [[Atlanta Federal Penitentiary]] was burned. *[[Centennial Olympic Park bombing]] — Killed 2 people and injured 111 during the [[1996 Summer Olympics]]. *[[Mark O. Barton]] - Known for the July 29, 1999 murders of 12 people and wounding of 13 more at two Atlanta day trading firms. *[[Brian Nichols]] — Known for 2005 escape and killing spree in the [[Fulton County Courthouse (Georgia)|Fulton County Courthouse]] and later killing an off-duty [[Special agent|federal agent]].
==See also== *[[Crime in Georgia]] *[[Law of Georgia (U.S. state)]] *[[FBI Atlanta Field Office]] *[[Crime in the United States]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.spotcrime.com/ga/atlanta Atlanta Crime Map] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20031204191600/http://atlantapd.org/index.asp Atlanta Police Department] *[https://archive.is/20130128051149/http://crime.mapatl.com/ Atlanta Crime & Sex Offenders]
{{Atlanta, Georgia}}
[[Category:Crime in Atlanta| ]] [[Category:Crime in the United States by city|Atlana]]
